description: The 'draw_box_plots' function generates box plots from given data, which are used for visualizing the distribution of numerical data and their properties such as center, spread and skewness. It is an essential tool in statistics and data analysis.
example_usage:
# Example usage for draw_box_plots
result = draw_box_plots(data)

stimulus_type_specification.title: Available Images: Box Plots for Data Visualization
stimulus_type_specification.description: The images generated by this function are box plots, which are a standardized way of displaying the distribution of data based on a five number summary ('minimum', first quartile (Q1), median, third quartile (Q3), and 'maximum'). These plots can provide detailed insights about the data including its symmetry, skewness, and outliers if any. The colors of the box plots are randomly selected from a predefined color palette, providing a visually appealing and distinct representation for each box plot.

details: The box in the plot represents the interquartile range (IQR) which is the range between the first quartile (25th percentile) and the third quartile (75th percentile).
The line inside the box represents the median of the data.

The 'whiskers' extending from the box indicate variability outside the upper and lower quartiles, hence they are also a measure of statistical dispersion. The position of the whiskers is set by default to 1.5*IQR from the edges of the box.
Outliers are sometimes plotted as individual dots that are in-line with whiskers.

stimulus_type_specification.educational_purpose: Box plots are a great way to visualize the distribution of data, and they can be very useful in the classroom for teaching students about statistics. They provide a visual representation of the data's quartiles, median, and potential outliers. This can help students better understand these concepts and how they relate to data distribution. Additionally, by comparing box plots, students can make comparisons between different data sets in a meaningful way.

educational_standards.description: Identify samples that are representative, random or biased.
Understand that a set of data collected to answer a statistical question has a data distribution which can be described by its center, spread, and overall shape.

educational_standards.display_name: Interpret Measures of Center and Variability
educational_standards.description: Interpret given statistical summaries—mean/median (measures of center) and range/IQR/MAD (measures of variability)—to describe what is typical and how much values vary in real-world contexts.
Display numerical data on box plots.

educational_standards.display_name: Finding Quantitative Measures from Charts and Graphs
educational_standards.description: Interpret charts and graphs to find mean, median, mode, and range.

Informally assess the degree of visual overlap of two numerical data distributions with similar variabilities, measuring the difference between the centers by expressing it as a multiple of a measure of variability.

educational_standards.display_name: Using Random Samples to Compare Populations
educational_standards.description: Use measures of center and measures of variability for numerical data from random samples to draw informal comparative inferences about two populations.
